docs.lead_paragraph: For 39 of his 59 years, Walter Jeck has been pursuing what might be termed the paper chase of terror, mining a way through mountains of documents here whose staggering details and dimensions illuminate the Third Reich's commitment to the bureaucracy of genocide. Here, he says, is a death book from the Buchenwald concentration camp, the names inscribed in ink on ruled paper, recording every last victim who died of starvation or disease or was ''shot while trying to escape.'' Here is Buchenwald's roll-call, until the day before the Americans liberated it on April 11, 1945.

headline.main: File Search Casts Light On Victims Of Nazi Era

docs.abstract: Walter Jeck pursues what might be termed a paper chase of terror, seeking to document and identify victims of Nazi persecution; Jeck, who is with International Tracing Service in Arolsen, Germany, is confronted daily with previous generation's genocide, documented in staggering 47 million file cards that yield clues to histories of 15 million people (L)
docs.snippet: For 39 of his 59 years, Walter Jeck has been pursuing what might be termed the paper chase of terror, mining a way through mountains of documents here whose staggering details and dimensions illuminate the Third Reich's commitment to the bureaucracy...

docs.lead_paragraph: With a thump, President Clinton dropped his four-volume, $1.69 trillion budget proposal for fiscal year 1998 on Congress' doorstep last week. Muttering about lessons learned in previous budget brawls, Republicans carried it inside for inspection, rather than dumping it straight in the trash as they had for two years running. Republicans kept saying things that would sound incredibly mean to anyone but a member of the Clinton Administration accustomed to even crueler derisions after a budget proposal. ''I am gravely depressed about what I have seen,'' said Senator Trent Lott, the Republican majority leader.
docs.abstract: Republicans have responded cautiously, but negatively, to Pres Clinton's budget proposal (S)
docs.snippet: With a thump, President Clinton dropped his four-volume, $1.69 trillion budget proposal for fiscal year 1998 on Congress' doorstep last week. Muttering about lessons learned in previous budget brawls, Republicans carried it inside for inspection,...

docs.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, the shorthand by which the World Economic Forum's annual jamboree in this ski resort is known, is over for this year. Nelson Mandela, Yasir Arafat, Bill Gates and Jack Welch, among others, spoke. And while they were not talking -- in fact, even while they were up there on the podium -- the business elite used their view from these Alpine peaks to ponder and discuss where the world is and where it may be going, in forums large and small. So your company declined to pay the $20,000 entry fee, plus expenses, to send you to Davos? Do not despair. If Tom Peters, the consultant, can offer ''Business School in a Box,'' surely what goes on in Davos can be summarized in, say, 1,200 words. Here's the skinny you need to make it look like you were here.

headline.main: A Quick Guide to Big Ideas, if You Didn't Get to Davos

docs.abstract: *Guide to some of 'big ideas' discussed at World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, for benefit of those who were unable to attend; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 50 million Americans are now enrolled in health maintenance organizations. Nearly three-quarters of those who receive health insurance through their employers are covered by some type of managed-care plan, up from 51 percent just two years ago. The growing dominance of managed care has helped control health care cost increases. Over time, managed care may also improve medical outcomes by emphasizing preventive care, coordinating the delivery of services and reducing the number of unnecessary procedures and tests. But as managed care becomes the primary structure for the delivery of health services in this country, the trend raises consumer concerns about access, quality and choice. Managed care reduces choice in doctors and places more control in the hands of plan administrators. In well-run plans, enrollees benefit from lower costs and more efficient services. But that is not the case with all managed care. Consumer anxiety is further heightened when employers offer employees little, if any, choice in plans.
docs.abstract: Editorial supports a comprehensive approach to the regulation of the managed care industry, now the primary structure for the delivery of health services in the US; lauds Managed Care Consumer Protection Act, a bipartisan model bill that has been introduced in several states (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A FEDERAL law passed last summer allows the self-employed to deduct almost half of the cost of their health care coverage. But a little-known part of the tax code might offer a better deal: it allows a 100 percent deduction and even lets companies write off other medical expenses. While any company can take advantage of this, tax advisers say the deduction makes the most sense for a mom-and-pop business in which one spouse is the employer and the other is the employee. The Federal tax code -- mainly section 105, which deals with medical expenses -- allows businesses to deduct the cost of employee health care premiums and any medical, dental and vision care expenses that are not insured.

headline.main: A Little-Known Break For Mom-and-Pop Shops
